018package org.tquadrat.foundation.value.api;
019
020import static org.apiguardian.api.API.Status.STABLE;
021
022import java.io.Serializable;
023import java.math.BigDecimal;
024
025import org.apiguardian.api.API;
026import org.tquadrat.foundation.annotation.ClassVersion;
027
028/**
029 *  The implementations of this interface are used to give (numerical) values a
030 *  dimension and a measuring unit. So {@code 3.1415} is just a number, but it
031 *  could also stand for a length ({@code 3.1415&nbsp;m}), a time
032 *  ({@code 3.1415&nbsp;s}) or even the fuel consumption of a car
033 *  ({@code 3.1415&nbsp;l/100&nbsp;km}). Depending on the dimension, different
034 *  values could be equal:
035 *  <pre><code>1.0&nbsp;m == 100.0&nbsp;cm</code></pre>
036 *  and should be treated as such.<br>
037 *  <br>This interface should be implemented as
038 *  {@link java.lang.Enum enum}s, where the enum values are the units,
039 *  and as such they should provide a method to retrieve an {@code enum} value
040 *  (a unit) by the respective
041 *  {@linkplain #unitSymbol() symbole}.
042 *
043 *  @extauthor Thomas Thrien - thomas.thrien@tquadrat.org
044 *  @version $Id: Dimension.java 820 2020-12-29 20:34:22Z tquadrat $
045 *  @since 0.1.0
046 *
047 *  @UMLGraph.link
048 */
049@ClassVersion( sourceVersion = "$Id: Dimension.java 820 2020-12-29 20:34:22Z tquadrat $" )
050@API( status = STABLE, since = "0.1.0" )
051public interface Dimension extends Serializable
052{
053        /*-----------*\
054    ====** Constants **========================================================
055        \*-----------*/
056    /**
057     *  Message: Unknown Unit.
058     */
059    public static final String MSG_UnknownUnit = "Unknown unit: %s";
060
061        /*---------*\
062    ====** Methods **==========================================================
063        \*---------*/
064    /**
065     *  Returns the base unit.<br>
066     *  <br>E.g. for length, the base unit would be Meter (m), for mass, it is
067     *  Kilogram (kg), and so on.
068     *
069     *  @param  <D> The implementing class for the interface.
070     *  @return The base unit.
071     */
072    public <D extends Dimension> D baseUnit();
073
074    /**
075     *  {@inheritDoc}<br>
076     *  <br>Dimensions are equal when they are identical; therefore they
077     *  should be implemented as <i>Multitons</i> (constants of the
078     *  implementing class, without the option to create additional instances
079     *  on runtime).
080     *
081     *  @see Object#equals(Object)
082     */
083    @Override
084    public boolean equals( Object o );
085
086    /**
087     *  Returns the factor that is used to convert a value from this unit
088     *  to the base unit.<br>
089     *  <br>For length, if you have to convert a
090     *  Centimeter value to Meter, you will divide that by 100 or multiply it
091     *  with a <i>factor</i> of 0.01.<br>
092     *  <br>For the base unit, the factor is 1.0.
093     *
094     *  @return The factor.
095     *
096     *  @see #baseUnit()
097     */
098    public BigDecimal factor();
099
100    /**
101     *  Returns the default precision for this unit that is used when the
102     *  respective value is converted to a String.
103     *
104     *  @return The mantissa length for a value with this unit.
105     */
106    public default int getPrecision() { return 1; }
107
108    /**
109     *  Returns the internal name of the dimension.
110     *
111     *  @return The internal name.
112     */
113    public String name();
114
115    /**
116     *  {@inheritDoc}
117     *
118     *  @note {@code toString()} should be implemented to return the result of
119     *      {@link #unitSymbol()}
120     *      instead of
121     *      {@link Enum#name()}, as it would be the default for {@code enum}s.
122     */
123    @Override
124    public String toString();
125
126    /**
127     *  Returns the unit symbol for the dimension as a single line string.<br>
128     *  <br>For a length, this would be &quot;m&quot;, for a speed
129     *  &quot;km/h&quot;, and for an acceleration, it could be
130     *  &quot;m/(s^2)&quot;.
131     *
132     *  @return The unit.
133     */
134    public String unitSymbol();
135}
136//  interface Dimension
137
138/*
139 *  End of File
140 */
